entry.title: Combined summary - Testnet3 difficulty transition problem?
entry.summary: The context discusses two blocks, block 38304 and block 40320, which are difficulty transition blocks. While both of these blocks have difficulties that should make them impossible to mine, block 40320 has a difficulty of 1 due to a special testnet rule. It was previously believed that this rule could not be applied to difficulty transition blocks. However, bitcoinj based clients do not advance their blockchain past block 40319, likely due to the discrepancy in the difficulty of block 40320. This information suggests that there may be additional rules or exceptions related to difficulty transitions that are not yet fully understood. In an email exchange on December 22, 2012, Andreas Schildbach asked about two blocks with difficulty transitions. While block 40320 had a difficulty of 1, Schildbach thought that this exception could not be used on difficulty transition blocks. However, he was informed that the difficulty change is relative to the prior block's difficulty, so if the penultimate block in the difficulty cycle is under the special rule, the difficulty change will be relative to 1. The timewarp attack had been added to the testnet chain, but the test case was intentionally avoided in case they wanted to fix it before testnet3's release.Furthermore, the context implies that someone said "I pushed a fix for this," indicating that they have solved an issue or bug related to some kind of software or program. The statement "pushed a fix" suggests that the solution was uploaded or implemented through a version control system, such as Git. It is possible that this statement was made in a team setting, where multiple people were working on the same project. Regardless of their position, the fact that they were able to solve the issue and push a fix suggests that they have some level of technical expertise and are proactive in ensuring the smooth operation of the system or application.
